stream_context.summary: Kaze iterates on the Cowboy level’s underground Mole Hideout encounter, implementing rock-throwing enemies that aim at Mario and brainstorming how to turn the room into a satisfying “boss”/star challenge. He also showcases a major engine change: replacing SM64’s collision with a custom collision system for stability, and he gives a concrete project-status update (remaining levels, ~80% complete) plus a brief post-release plan (Kickstarter for an original game).
stream_context.significance_reason: He reveals a major technical milestone (a fully new collision system replacing SM64’s) and gives a clear production milestone update (~80% complete, remaining courses). The stream also effectively locks in the Mole Hideout encounter design (randomized-hole rock throwers; stars 1–2 essentially done).

findings.summary: Kaze replaced Super Mario 64’s original collision handling with a completely new custom collision system, citing the original as “unusable” and emphasizing improved stability (reduced sticking on awkward geometry).
findings.quote: I made a completely new collision system. I said, fuck Mario 64’s collision. It is unusable. We have our completely own collision system now. And it’s so much more stable.

findings.summary: The new collision system changes emergent movement tech: BLJ becomes harder or sometimes removed as a side effect of more stable physics, which Kaze considers undesirable; he would prefer BLJ remain possible in at least some spots.
findings.quote: By making more stable physics, it just so happened to remove BLJ. And I consider that a bad thing, actually.

findings.summary: Kaze articulates a rule for bug preservation: exploits/bugs that require intentional effort (like BLJ) can stay because they won’t affect normal players, but glitches that can happen accidentally should be removed.
findings.quote: If there’s a bug in Mario 64 that you only encounter if you do it on purpose, I’ll leave it in the game. But if it can happen on accident, I’ll remove it.

findings.summary: To make mole-thrown rocks reach Mario reliably, Kaze computes the correct initial Y-velocity based on discrete per-frame gravity steps (a frame-step sum), then applies that to aim at Mario’s current position.
Kaze explicitly rejects predictive enemy aiming; rocks target Mario’s current position rather than leading him, because the goal is readable/fair behavior rather than anti-speedrun countermeasures.
findings.quote: It shoots exactly where Mario is at. It’s not predictive. I don’t want this to be predictive.

findings.summary: He notes that some collision on the Cowboy level bridge was temporarily removed “for RAM reasons,” implying memory constraints are still actively shaping level geometry/collision decisions.
findings.quote: I had to remove the collision here for RAM reasons for now.

findings.summary: Boss-fight brainstorming outcome: Kaze moves away from a ‘five separate moles’ boss concept (risk of visual clutter and bland repetition) toward a simpler challenge where multiple moles pop out of randomized holes; the encounter serves as a mechanic introduction before a harder variant.

Kaze considers (and mostly rejects) alternative encounter concepts: pure survival/waves, a power-up requirement (e.g., hard-hat/bombs), a ‘star popping in/out’ gimmick, or skipping a boss entirely and just awarding a star; he gravitates toward the simplest readable solution.

Kaze explains his critique-processing method: he tries to address the underlying feeling behind feedback rather than literal suggestions, arguing that experienced critics can overfit to “parameters” instead of the emotions the game evokes.
findings.quote: When I receive a criticism, I try to figure out what the person was feeling that’s wrong… I try to address their feeling instead of their actual critique.

findings.summary: While debugging coins on enemy death, he points out SM64 has a built-in safety mechanism that limits coin spawning (to prevent runaway spawning from respawning actors), which he must satisfy by setting the spawn amount before calling the spawn routine.

Kaze comments on N64 performance constraints as largely bandwidth-related; he speculates that with more memory bandwidth games could run significantly faster, and observes that CPU becomes the bottleneck mainly when code is not optimized.

Project status update: after this work, he estimates the hack is ~80% complete, with “three more main courses, two side levels, and one Bowser level” remaining. He states the Mole Hideout area’s first two stars are effectively done and the next target is star three: the ‘Goomba imposter tower.’
findings.quote: The levels are left to make after this: three more main courses and two side levels and one Bowser level—we’re like 80% of the way there… star one and two are done and we need to move on to star three… the Goomba imposter tower.

findings.summary: Post-release plan: Kaze intends to launch a Kickstarter for an original 3D platformer alongside Return to Yoshi’s Island’s release and hopes to hire other ROM hackers to help transition into that project.
findings.quote: Alongside the release of Return to Yoshi’s Island I’ll probably launch a Kickstarter for my own game… and then hopefully I can hire some other ROM hackers to work on it with me.

zeina.summary: Zeina is mentioned as not being home during this stream (no direct collaboration moment captured here).

findings.summary: Viewers propose multiple boss/encounter variations (e.g., bomb-only damage, power-up gating, tank joke, star gimmicks). Kaze uses the suggestions as a brainstorming springboard but ultimately chooses a random-hole multi-mole approach for clarity and western theme consistency.

key_stories.title: Replacing SM64 collision with a custom system
key_stories.summary: Kaze shows off a newly implemented collision system intended to fix sticking and instability in complex geometry. The change alters classic emergent behaviors (like BLJ) and forces him to think about which legacy quirks should remain.
key_stories.challenge: Vanilla SM64 collision behavior is described as unstable/unusable for his level geometry and gameplay needs, causing sticking and unreliable movement interactions.
key_stories.process: He implements an entirely separate collision system and stress-tests it in ‘fucked up spots’ of the Cowboy level, checking for stability and edge cases like ceilings and movement tech.
key_stories.outcome: Movement becomes significantly more stable, but BLJ becomes harder/less available; Kaze frames that as a negative side effect and suggests he still wants BLJ to exist somewhere.
key_stories.key_quote: By making more stable physics, it just so happened to remove BLJ. And I consider that a bad thing, actually.

key_stories.title: Mole Hideout encounter design: from ‘boss’ to readable challenge
key_stories.summary: Kaze enters the Mole Hideout with a partially built arena and iterates on how the encounter should end (boss vs. simple enemy clear vs. star reward). He converges on randomized-hole moles throwing rocks at Mario, tuned for readability and pacing.
key_stories.challenge: A five-mole ‘boss’ risks being visually cluttered and not fun; the arena was built before the boss concept was fully decided.
key_stories.process: He prototypes rock-throwing behavior, tunes damage, debugs death/coin drops, and weighs multiple design suggestions (survival, power-up gating, star gimmicks) before choosing a simpler randomized-hole structure.
key_stories.outcome: He considers the boss fight ‘basically done’ pending animations/decorations; stars 1–2 in this area are effectively complete, and the next task is star 3 (Goomba imposter tower).
key_stories.key_quote: I think nine Monty Moles is really the best thing we can do here… But they switch holes. Let’s do that.

open_questions.topic: Custom collision system details and tradeoffs
open_questions.context: Kaze states he replaced SM64 collision entirely for stability and that it impacted BLJ availability, but he does not explain how the system works, how much of the engine it replaces, or how compatibility with SM64-level data is maintained.
questions: What specifically about SM64’s collision was ‘unusable’ for Return to Yoshi’s Island—sticking, edge snapping, floor/ceiling classification, triangle limits, precision, or something else?
How is the new collision system implemented (math approach, spatial partitioning, triangle queries), and how hard was it to integrate into the decomp codebase?
What did you have to give up (performance, memory, edge-case accuracy) to gain stability on N64 hardware?

Do you plan to intentionally re-enable BLJ-like behavior in specific places, or accept that the hack’s movement tech will differ from vanilla SM64? If intentional, how do you ‘design in’ an exploit safely?

open_questions.topic: N64 RAM constraints shaping level collision
open_questions.context: Kaze mentions temporarily removing bridge collision “for RAM reasons,” implying collision/geo budgeting is still a live production constraint.
questions: What exactly was consuming RAM on the bridge section—collision triangles, visual geometry, actors, or other level scripts?
What is your working budget/target for collision triangles or area complexity per course, and how often do you have to cut collision to fit?
Is the plan to re-add bridge collision later via optimization, streaming, or re-authoring geometry?

open_questions.topic: Mole Hideout encounter goals and tuning
open_questions.context: Kaze settles on randomized-hole rock throwers and non-predictive aiming, but details about difficulty targets, readability, and reward structure are not finalized on-stream.
questions: What player skill are you trying to teach in this room—reading telegraphs, timing jumps, spatial positioning, or resource use?
How do you decide between ‘boss’ vs. ‘enemy clear’ for a star objective in this hack—what makes something worthy of a boss?
What animations/telegraphs are still needed to make the rock throws feel fair (wind-up, sound cues, camera framing)?

open_questions.topic: Production roadmap and remaining content at ~80%
open_questions.context: Kaze lists remaining level counts and names the next objective (Goomba imposter tower), but doesn’t map these to courses, themes, or risk areas.
questions: Which specific courses/areas remain in ‘three main courses, two side levels, and one Bowser level,’ and which are the riskiest/most time-consuming?
What does the ‘Goomba imposter tower’ star involve mechanically and narratively, and why is it a good fit for the next milestone?
What’s the definition of ‘80%’ here—content complete, or also polish (animations, music integration, bugfixing, performance passes)?

open_questions.context: Kaze says he may run a Kickstarter for an original platformer around the hack’s release and hopes to hire ROM hackers to help.
questions: Why pair the Kickstarter with Return to Yoshi’s Island’s release—audience timing, financial runway, or creative momentum?
What parts of the ROM-hack team pipeline translate to the original game (level art, animation, music), and what will need entirely new roles?
How will you handle the legal/PR optics of launching a commercial Kickstarter adjacent to a Nintendo-adjacent fan project?
